turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: You have only to stretch out your hand, take up the glass and drink a little.

turns.speaker: MRS. CORTEZ
turns.text: It won't hurt.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Ann?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Graham Dalton.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That was quick.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: False alarm.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh. Well, please sit down.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: We... don't usually let people smoke in the house. We have a patio if you --

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Oh, no problem. It can wait.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Do you have other things?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.  Oh, you mean to bring in! No. Yes, I have some other things, no, I don't need to bring them in. This is all I need to stay here.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Have you ever been on television?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Television?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No. Why?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Curious.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Graham is an unusual name.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yeah, I guess it is. My mother is a complete Anglophile, anything British makes her drool like a baby. She probably heard the name in some movie. She's a prisoner of public television now.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, uh-huh.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Are you uncomfortable with my appearance?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, I think you look... fine.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Oh. Well, maybe I'm uncomfortable with my appearance. I feel a little out of place in these surroundings.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I used to take great pleasure in that, being purposefully different, rubbing people's noses in it. Didn't you do that when you were younger?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, not really.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Oh. Well, I did. I was in a band once, and the music was always secondary to just flat out offending as many people as possible.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You play an instrument?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, I was in charge of kind of standing at the microphone and reciting these really depressing lyrics in a monotone. The whole thing was really... irrelevant. How do you like being married?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, I like it. I like it very much.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What about it do you like? I'm not being critical, I'd really like to know.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well... well, the clich√© about the security of it, that's really true. We own a house, and I really like that, you know? And I like that John was just made junior partner, so he has a steady job and he's not some...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: ...free-lance. You know.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. So you feel security, stability. Like things are going to last awhile.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, definitely. I mean, just this past year has gone by like phew! I hardly even knew it passed.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Did you know that if you shut someone up in a room, and the only clock he has reference to runs two hours slow for every twenty-four, that his body will eventually adjust to that schedule? Simply because the mind honestly perceives that twenty-six hours are twenty-four, the body follows. And then there are sections of time. Your life can be broken down into the sections of time that formed your personality . For instance, when I was twelve, I had an eleven minute conversation with my father that to this day defines our relationship. Now, I'm not saying that everything happened in that specific section of time, but the events of my childhood involving my father led up to, and then were crystallized in, that eleven minutes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, uh-huh.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Anyway, I think the mind is very flexible as far as time is concerned.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You mean like "time flies"?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Exactly. I would say the fact that you feel the first year of your marriage has gone by quickly means lots of things. Or could mean lots of things.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How long has it been since you've seen John?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Nine years.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Nine years?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. I was surprised that he accepted when I asked if I could stay here until I found a place.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why? Didn't you know him well?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I knew him very well. We were extremely close until I dropped out.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why'd you drop out?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Oh, lots of reasons, most of them boring. But, up until I dropped out, John and I were... very much alike.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That's hard to believe. The two of you seem so different.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I would imagine that we are, now. I think I'm ready to use the bathroom, finally.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: This food is excellent.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Mother, father, sister.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Sister older or younger?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Younger.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Who's Elizabeth?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do I pay taxes? Of course I pay taxes, only a liar doesn't pay taxes, I'm not a liar. A liar is the second lowest form of human being.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What's the first?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Lawyers.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Would you mind?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Okay, I will!!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Maybe you'll understand this, because you know John, but he confuses me sometimes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: How do you mean?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yeah, I know. I mean, I'm not saying I know people think you're a bitch, I'm saying I know what you mean. And I don't even know that people think you're a bitch. Do they?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I feel like they do.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hmm. Well, maybe you are. Really, I wouldn't pay much attention.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I know that I just don't feel a connection with very many people, so I don't waste time with people I don't feel one with.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Right, right. I don't feel connected to many people, either. Other than John.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Can I tell you something personal? I feel like I can. It's something I couldn't tell John. Or wouldn't, anyway.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's up to you. But I warn you, if you tell me something personal, I might do the same.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Okay. I think... I think sex is overrated. I think people place way too much importance on it. And I think that stuff about women wanting it just as bad is crap. I m not saying women don't want it, I just don't think they want it for the reason men think they do.  I'm getting confused.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Do you understand what I'm trying to say?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I think so. I remember reading somewhere that men learn to love what they're attracted to, whereas women become more and more attracted to the person they love.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes! Yes! I think that's very true. Very.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: So what about kids?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Kids? What about them?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do you want them?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, actually, I do. But John doesn't. At least not right now.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Why is that?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know, he just said he wants to wait. I quit asking.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So what's your personal thing? Are you really going to tell me something personal?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do you want me to?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: As long as it's not... gross, you know? Like some scar or something. It has to be like mine, like something about you.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Agreed.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You're what?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Impotent.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You are?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Well, let me put it this way: I cannot achieve an erection while in the presence of another person. So, for all practical purposes, I am impotent.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Does it bother you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Not usually. I mean, honestly, I haven't known many guys that could think straight with an erection, so I feel I'm way ahead of the game as far as being clear-headed goes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well... are you self-conscious about it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I am self-conscious, but not in the same way that you are. You have got to be the most attractive self- conscious person I've ever seen.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why do you say I'm self-conscious?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Well, I've been watching you. I've watched you eat, I've watched you speak, I've watched the way you move, and I see somebody who is extremely conscious of being looked at. I think you really believe that people are looking at you all the time. And you know what?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: They are looking at you. Ann, you are truly breathtaking. I don't know if you understand how your appearance can affect people. Men want to possess you, women wish they looked like you. And those that don't or can't resent you. And the fact that you're a nice person just makes it worse.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: My therapist said that --

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You're in therapy?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Aren't you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hah! No, I'm not. Actually, I used to be, but the therapist I had was really ineffectual in helping me deal with my problems. Of course, I lied to him constantly, so I guess I can't hold him totally responsible...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So you don't believe in therapy?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I believe in it for some people. I mean, for me it was silly, I was confused going in. So I just formed my own personal theory that you should never take advice from someone of the opposite sex that doesn't know you intimately.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, my therapist knows me intimately.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You had sex with you therapist?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Oh, see, I meant someone you've had sex with. That's part of the theory.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Excuse me for asking, but how would you know?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Well, I wasn't always impotent.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Now, you said never take advice from someone that you don't know intimately, right?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Basically, yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So since I've never had sex with you, by your own advice I shouldn't accept your advice.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's correct.  Bit of a dilemma, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Hi!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Ann. Hello.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Are you in the middle of something?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Nothing I can't finish later.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I just wanted to see how the place looked furnished.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Not much to see, I'm afraid. I'm sort of cultivating a minimalist vibe.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Somehow I imagined books. I thought you would have like a whole lot of books and be reading all the time.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What are these?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Videotapes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I can see that. What are they?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's a personal project I'm working on.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What kind of personal project?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Oh, just a personal project like anyone else's personal project. Mine's just a little more personal.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Who's Donna?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Donna?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Donna. On this tape it says "Donna".

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Donna was a girl I knew in Florida.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You went out with her?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Because I enjoy interviewing women more than men.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: All of these are interviews?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Can we look at one?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Because I promised each subject that no one would look at the tape except me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What... what are these interviews about?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: The... interviews are about sex, Ann.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: About sex?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What about sex?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Everything about sex.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Like what they've done, what they do, what they don't do, what they want to do but are afraid to ask for, what they won't do even if asked. Anything I can think of.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You just ask them questions?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: And they just answer them?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Mostly. Sometimes they do things.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: To you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, not to me, for me, for the camera.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't... why... why do you do this?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm sorry this came up.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: This is just... so...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Maybe you want to go.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm not sure why I came here. I had kind of decided not to talk to you after... you know.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John and Cynthia have been... "fucking".

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You know?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How did you know?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: She said it on her tape.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Ann, when would I have told you? We were not speaking, if you recall.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: But even if we had been speaking, I wouldn't have told you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's not my place to tell you these things, Ann. You have to find out by yourself or from John directly. You have to trust me on this.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do you think that's such a good idea?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Don't you want to make one?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. But I sense the element of revenge here.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What difference does it make why I do it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I want you to be aware of what you're doing and why, because I know that this is not the sort of thing you would do in a normal frame of mind.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What would you know about a normal frame of mind?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's a good question.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What do you have to do to get ready?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Load a new tape, turn the camera on.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Then do it.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How do you pay for all this? I mean, rent, and tapes and this equipment.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I have money.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What will you do when the money runs out?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It won't. Are you ready?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Tell me your name.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Ann Bishop Millaney.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Tell me your name.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Ann Bishop Millaney.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You are married, correct?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do you talk to him?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: When we're making love?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Sometimes. Afterward.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Does he go down on you?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You don't know what I'm thinking.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's a simple question. Have you ever thought of having -- making love with someone other than your husband?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Is he going to see this?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Absolutely not.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Did you have sex before you were married?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Did the person you made love with satisfy you more than your husband?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't see what difference it makes, I mean, I can think what I want.  I don't know if I want to do this anymore, I'm afraid... I don't mind answering the questions so much, but if somebody were to see this...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: At some level, I don't understand your nervousness. Have you decided to leave John?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, I have. I will.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Then as far as this taping goes, you have nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I guess not.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do you want me to stop?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Are there people other than your previous lover that you have fantasized about?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes. Whenever... all right, look. Whenever I see a man that I think is attractive, I wonder what it would be like with him, I mean, I'm just curious, I don't act on it, but I hate that I think that!! I wish I could just forget about that stuff!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Because that's how Cynthia thinks!! All she does is think about that stuff, and I hate that, I don't want to be like her, I don't want to be like her!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You're not like your sister. You couldn't be like her if you wanted to.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I know. Deep down, I know that. It just bothers me, when I have feelings or impulses that she has.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: So you do fantasize?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: About who?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I fantasized about you.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: About me?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Have you fantasized about me?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I thought I made that clear before, when I said I would go down on you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I remember. You could do that, couldn't you? Go down on me?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If I asked you to, would you? Not on tape, I mean?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: On tape?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: If I can't do it all, I don't want to do anything. And I can't do it all.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Can't or won't?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Can't.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You said you weren't always impotent.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's correct.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So you have had sex.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Who was the last person you had sex with?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Her name was Elizabeth.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So what happened? Was it so bad that it turned you off?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, it was wonderful. That wasn't the problem.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What was the problem?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: The problem was me. I was... I was a pathological liar. Or am, I should say. Lying is like alcoholism, one is always "recovering".

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So you lied to her?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. I did. Willfully and repeatedly.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I loved her for how good she made me feel, and I hated her for how good she made me feel. And at that time, I tended to express my feelings non- verbally. I couldn't handle anyone having that much control over my emotions.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: And now you can?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Now I make sure that no one has the opportunity to test me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Don't you get lonely?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: How could I, with all these nice people stopping by? The fact is that I've lived by myself for so long, I can't imagine living with another person. It's amazing what you can get used to if enough time goes by. And anyway, I'm asking the questions. Are you happy?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know anymore. I thought I was, but obviously I was wrong.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Did you confront John with the fact that you knew about him?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Not yet. I'm not sure I will. I just want out.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: If you do get out of your marriage, will you continue to be inhibited?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know. It all gets back to that Cynthia thing. I don't like her... eagerness. There's nothing left to imagine, there's no...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Subtlety?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Subtlety, yes. No subtlety. Plus, I've never really felt able to open up with anyone. I mean, that other person I told you about, I enjoyed making love with him a lot, but I still wasn't able to really let go. I always feel like I'm being watched and I shouldn't embarrass myself.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: And you feel the same way with John?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Kind of. I mean, John's like this kind of... craftsman. Like he's a carpenter, and he makes really good tables. But that's all he can make, and I don't need anymore tables.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Interesting analogy.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm babbling.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, you're not.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: God, I m so mad at him!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You should be. He lied to you. So did Cynthia.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, I know, but somehow I expect that from her, I mean, she'll do it with almost anybody, I don't know, I shouldn't stick up for her I guess, but him. He lied so... deeply!! Ooo, I want to watch him die!!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You're really never going to make love again?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm not planning on it.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If you were in love with me, would you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm not in love with you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But if you were?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I... I can't answer that precisely.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But I feel like maybe I could be really comfortable with you.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's very flattering.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So why won't you make love with me? Why wouldn't you, I mean?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Ann. Are you asking me hypothetically, or are you asking me for real, right now?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm asking for real. I want you to turn that camera off and make love with me. Will you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I've told you.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But I don't understand --

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Ann, it could happen to me all over again, don't you see? I could start to --

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But how do you know for sure, you have to try to find a way to fig --

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I couldn't face her if I had slept with somebody else.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Who? Elizabeth?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You mean you're still in contact with her?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But you're planning to be?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't know. Possibly.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Wait a minute, wait a minute. What's going on here? Did you come back here just to see her again?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Not entirely.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But that was part of it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Like maybe a big part?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Possibly.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Graham, I mean, what do you think her reaction is going to be if you contact her?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Look at you, look at what's happened to you, look how you've changed! Don't you think she will have changed?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't know. I really would rather not talk about it.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Whoa!! I'm so glad we got that on tape!! You won't answer a question about Elizabeth, but I have to answer all these intimate questions about my sex life!! Graham, what do you think she's going to make of all these videotapes? Are you going to tell her about them? I can't imagine her being too understanding about that. But since you don't lie anymore, you'll have to say something.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: As I said, I haven't decided what to do, exactly. Perhaps I won't do anything.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, you just moved here to think about it, right?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: All right, you want to talk about lies, let's talk about lies, Ann. Let's talk about lying to yourself. You haven't been able to sleep with your husband because you're no longer in love with him, and maybe you never were. You haven't been honest with yourself in longer than you can remember.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, you're right. But I never claimed to know everything like you, and have all these little theories. I'm still learning, I know that. But I don't feel like I've wasted time. If I had to go through my marriage to get to where I am right now, fine.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Don't do that.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Because.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: "Because"? That's not good enough. I asked you a question, Graham. I asked you "how does it feel"? How does it feel, Mr. I Want To Go Down On You But I Can't? Do you know how many people you've sucked into your weird little world? Including me? Come on, how does it feel?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I can't tell you like this.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm just going to keep asking until you answer. I'm sure there's plenty of tape.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't find this "turning the tables" thing very interesting --

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Come on!!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: All right!! All right!! You want to know? You want to know how I feel? I feel ashamed. Is that what you wanted to hear?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why are you ashamed?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Ann. Why is anybody anything? I think you have this idea that people are either all good or all bad, and you don't allow for any gray areas, and that's what most of us consist of.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You're not answering me.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Well, what kind of answer are you looking for, Ann? What is it exactly that you want to know?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I want to know why you are the way you are!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: And I'm telling you it's not any one thing that I can point to and say "That's why!" It doesn't work that way with people who have problems, Ann, it's not that neat, it's not that tidy! It's not a series of little boxes that you can line up and count. Things just don't happen that way.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But why can't you just put it all behind you? Can't you just forget it? All that stuff you did?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, Ann, I can't. I can't forget it. It's not something I can fix. It's difficult. There s something in my mind... the way my brain works...  God, Ann, when you're with another person, and you're... inside them, you're so vulnerable, you're revealing so much... there's no protection. And... somebody could say, or do something to you while you're in this... state of... nakedness. And they could hurt you without even knowing it. In a way that you couldn't even see.  And you would withdraw. To make sure it didn't happen again.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I want to touch you.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Graham...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm okay. It's okay.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's the first thing that ran through my mind when I saw you. I thought this is not the same man that rode the unicycle naked through the homecoming parade.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You did that?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, we get along okay. She's just very... she's an extrovert. I think she's loud. She probably wouldn't agree. Definitely wouldn't agree.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Are you going to see Elizabeth while you're here?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Graham and I were talking about apartments and I told him to check the Garden District, there are some nice little places there, garage apartments and stuff.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Stay away from the Garden District. Serious crime. I don't know what kind of place you're looking for, but there are a lot of studio-type apartments available elsewhere.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: John?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Mmmmm...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I called you Tuesday at 3:30 and they said you weren't in. Do you remember where you were?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Tuesday. I had a late lunch.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Did you see a message to call me when you got back in?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yes. I just got busy.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That's interesting, because I didn't leave a message.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Then maybe I saw an old message. There are a lot of them on my desk, you know.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Who'd you have lunch with?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I ate by myself.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Something wrong?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Are you having an affair?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus Christ, where'd that come from? I have a late lunch by myself and now I'm fucking somebody?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, are you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, I'm not. Frankly, I'm offended at the accusation.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: If I'm right, I want to know. I don't want you to lie. I'd be very upset, but not as upset as if I'd found out you'd been lying.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: There's nothing to know, Ann.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I can't tell you how upset I would be if you were lying.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Ann, you are completely paranoid. Not ten minutes ago I wanted to make love for the first time in weeks, and you act like I'm dipped in shit. You know, I think there are a lot of women that would be glad to have a young, straight male making a pretty good living beside them in bed with a hard on.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: My sister, for one. Is that who it is?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: For God's sake, Ann, I am not fucking your sister. I don't find her that attractive, for one.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Is that supposed to comfort me?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I was just saying, you know? I didn't get paranoid when you didn't want to make love. I could have easily assumed that you didn't want to because you were having an affair.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But I'm not.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm not either!!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why don't I believe you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, this conversation is utterly ridiculous. Maybe when you have some evidence, we should talk, but don't give me conjecture and intuition.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Always the lawyer.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Goddam right. I mean, can you imagine: "Your honor, I'm positive this man is guilty. I can't place him at the scene or establish a motive, but I have this really strong feeling."

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You've made your point.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm sorry. It's just... I'm under a lot of pressure with this Kirkland thing, it's my first big case as junior partner, and I work all day, I come home, I look forward to seeing you, and... it hurts that you accuse me like that.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm sorry, too. I... I get these ideas in my head, you know, and I have nothing to do all day but sit around and concoct these intricate scenarios. And then I want to believe it so I don't think I've wasted the whole day. Last week I was convinced you were having an affair with Cynthia, I don't know why.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't, either. I mean, Cynthia, of all people. She's so...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Loud.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah. Jeez, give me some credit.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I didn't say it was rational, I just said I was convinced.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Isn't therapy helping at all?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know. Sometimes I feel stupid babbling about my little problems while children are starving in the world.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Quitting your therapy won't feed the children of Ethiopia.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus Christ! What the hell happened? I came home and your car was gone, the door was open, I thought for sure you'd been abducted by some mad fucker, I was literally just calling the cops when you walked in. What happened?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I want out of this marriage.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I want out of this marriage.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: We'll call it uncontested or whatever. I just want out.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Where did you go when you left here?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I drove around. Then I went to talk with Graham.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Goddammit, goddammit!! That son of a bitch!!  Well, at least I know you didn't fuck him.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, but I wanted to. I really wanted to, partially just to piss you off.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You're leaving me for him, aren't you? Well, that makes a sad sort of sense. He can't, and you won't.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I'm not going to discuss this with you anymore. You're making no sense.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Answer me, godammit!! Did you make one of those tapes?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Goddam right.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Bastard...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He does.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You son of a bitch!!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Not very often.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I have thought about it, yes.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You bitch. I knew it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: God damn you!!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes, I remember. What do you do when these moods overtake you?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Nothing. I mean, nothing. I try not to do anything that will produce garbage, so obviously we're talking about eating and basic stuff like that. Did you know that the average person produces three pounds of garbage a day?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, I didn't.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Don't you think that's a lot of garbage? I'd really like to know where it's all going to go.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you have any idea what triggered this concern?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, this weekend John was taking out the garbage, and he kept spilling things out of the container, and I started imagining a container that grew garbage, like it just kept filling up and overflowing all by itself, and how could you stop that if it started happening?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ann, do you see a pattern here?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Well, last week we talked about your obsession with the families of airline fatalities, and now we're talking about your concern over the garbage problem.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, so?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: If you think about it, I think you'll see that the object of your obsession is invariably something negative that you couldn't possibly have any control over.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, do you think many people run around thinking about how happy they feel and how great things are? I mean, maybe they do, but I doubt those people are in therapy. Besides, being happy isn't all that great. My figure is always at its best when I'm depressed. The last time I was really happy I put on twenty-five pounds. I thought John was going to have a stroke.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you afraid of his reaction? Of his finding you silly for thinking of such things?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No. I don't know. I haven't told him about the garbage thing because I'm pissed off at him right now. He's letting some old college buddy stay at our house for a couple of days, and he didn't even ask me about it. I mean, I would've said yes, I just wish he would've asked.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What upsets you about that?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I guess I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset, I mean, it's his house, really, he pays the mortgage.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But he asked you to quit your job, and you do have housework.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yeah, I know.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: This unexpected visit notwithstanding, how are things with John?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Fine, I guess. Except right now I'm going through this where I don't want him to touch me.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: When did you begin having this feeling?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: About a week ago. I don't know what brought it on, I just started feeling like I didn't want him to touch me.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Prior to this feeling, were you comfortable having physical contact with him?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, yeah.  But see, I've never really been into sex that much, I mean, I like it and everything, it just does't freak me out, I wouldn't miss it, you know? But anyway, lately we haven't been doing anything at all. Like I said, it's not that I miss it, but I'm curious the way things kind of slacked off all of a sudden.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Perhaps he senses your hesitance at being touched.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But see, he stopped before I got that feeling, that's why it seems weird to me. I mean, I'm sure he wishes I would initiate things once in awhile, and I would except it never occurs to me, I'm always thinking about something else and then the few times that I have felt like starting something I was by myself.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you do anything?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you masturbate?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: God, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I take it you've never masturbated?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, I kind of tried once. It just seemed stupid, I kept seeing myself lying there and it seemed stupid, and kind of, uh, I don't know, and then I was wondering if my dead grandfather could see me doing this, and it just seemed like a dumb thing to be doing when we don't know what to do with all that garbage, you know?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So it was recently that you tried this.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, kind of recently, I guess. But not too recently.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, I don't know. The week started off okay, but then I was outside watering the plants, and I started feeling dizzy from the heat and that got me thinking about the Greenhouse Effect, so I went inside and turned on the air-conditioner full blast, and that made me feel a little better until I started thinking about radon leakage coming up through the floor, and --

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Radon leakage?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes, it's this radioactive gas in the ground, and houses kind of act like magnets to pull it up, and -- you've never heard of this?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, I haven't.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, the cumulative effect is not good, let me tell you.  I knew I shouldn't have watered those plants.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you confront John about the visitor?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What visitor?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The friend of John's that was staying at your house.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, Graham. No, I didn't talk to him about that. Actually, that turned out to be pretty interesting. I expected Graham to be this... well, like John, you know? I mean, he said they had gone to school together, so I was expecting lots of stories about getting drunk and secret handshakes and stuff. But he turned out to be this... this kind of character, I mean, he's kind of arty but okay, you know?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Is he still at your house?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, he left last week.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you find him attractive?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What do you mean, like physically?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Let me rephrase. Were you attracted to him?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I guess, but not because of the way he looked or anything. He's just so different, somebody new to have a conversation with. I'm just tired of talking to other couples about whether or not they're going to buy the station wagon, you know? It's just boring. I don't know, he was just different. And he's really on about truth a lot, being honest, and I like that, I felt comfortable around him.  After he left I had a dream that he signed a lease to rent our guest room.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What brought this on?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I've been thinking about it for awhile, and then I was talking to somebody who kind of put things in perspective for me.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I thought that's what I did. Who was it that you talked to?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That guy Graham I told you about. He said taking advice from someone you don't know intimately was... well, he said a lot of stuff.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ann, in life one has to be aware of hidden agendas.  Did it occur to you that Graham may have his own reasons for not wanting you to be in therapy?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What do you mean? I don't understand.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: It's possible that Graham has hidden motives for disliking therapy and/or therapists. Perhaps he has problems of his own that he is unwilling to deal with, and he would like to see other people, you for instance, wallow in their situation just as he does. Do you think that's possible?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You understand that you are free to leave therapy at any time?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That you are under no obligation to me?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you want to leave therapy?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you feel there is more progress to be made?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I'm glad you feel that way, because I feel that way, too.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But you don't have hidden motives for feeling that way, right?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I hate my sister.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Because all she thinks about are these guys she's after and I just hate her she's such a little slut I thought that in high school and I think that now. Why do people have to be so obsessed with sex all what's the big damn deal? I mean, it's okay and everything, but I don't understand when people let it control them, control their lives, why do they do that?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: There are many things that can exert control over one's life, good and bad. Religion, greed, philanthropy, drugs.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I know, but this... I just feel like everybody I know right now is obsessed with sex.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know. He went to school here, then he was in New York for awhile, then Philadelphia, and then just kind of travelling around.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Must be nice. So, what's he like, is he like John?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, not at all. Actually, I don't think John likes him much anymore. He said he thought Graham had gotten strange.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Is he? Strange, I mean?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Not really. Maybe if I just saw him on the street I'd have said that, but after talking to him... he's just kind of... I don't know, unusual.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Uh-huh. So what's he look like?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I just want to know what he looks like, is all.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why, so you can go after him?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Jesus, Ann, get a life. I just asked what he looked like.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Besides, even if I decided to fuck his brains out, what business is that of yours?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Do you have to say that?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You know what. You say it just to irritate me.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I say it because it's descriptive.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, he doesn't strike me as the kind of person that would go in for that sort of thing, anyway.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Ann, you always underestimate me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, I wonder why.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I think you're afraid to put the two of us in the same room together. I think you're afraid he'll be undeniably drawn to me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, for God's sake. Really, Cynthia, really, I don't think he's your type.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: "My type"? What is this bullshit? How would you know what "my type" is?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I have a pretty good idea.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Ann, you don't have a clue. Look, I don't even know why we're discussing this, I'll just call him myself.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He doesn't have a phone.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, I'll call him when he does.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But he won't.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He's not getting a phone, he doesn't like talking on the phone.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Oh, please. Okay, so give me the Zen master's address, I'll think of a reason to stop by.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Let me talk to him first.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Why? Just give me the address, you won't even have to be involved.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't feel right just giving you the address so that you can go over there and...

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: And what?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: And... do whatever it is you do.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Lose something?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: That goddam diamond stud earring that cost me a fucking fortune.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Are you getting Mom something for her birthday?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I don't know, I'll get her a card or something.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: A card? For her fiftieth birthday?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What's wrong with that?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Don't you think she deserves a little more than a card? I mean, the woman gave birth to you. It's her fiftieth birthday --

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Will you stop? Jesus.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I just thought it might --

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Okay, Ann, okay. How about this: you buy her something nice, and I'll pay for half. All right?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Good. Now, if you'll pardon me, I have to go to work.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I was thinking maybe I shouldn't be in therapy anymore.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't... he doesn't want you to come over.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What do you mean he doesn't want me to come over? Did you tell him about me?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, I didn't.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Because I never got around to it.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, why?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Because. Cynthia, look, John was right. Graham is strange. Very strange. You don't want to get involved with him.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What the hell happened over there? Did he make a pass at you?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Then what's the story, what's this "strange" bullshit all of a sudden? Is he drowning puppies, or what?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, it's nothing like that.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, what? Is he dangerous?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No, he's not dangerous. Not physically.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, what, then?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Then why'd you call me?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: He just asked me questions.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What kinds of questions?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Questions about sex.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Well, like what did he ask, exactly?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, like, I don't want to tell you, exactly.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, so you'll let a total stranger record your sexual life on tape, but you won't tell your own sister?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Apparently.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Did he ask you to take your clothes off?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Cynthia!

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What!?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Why did you do that?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Because I wanted to.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But why did you want to?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I wanted him to see me.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Cynthia, who knows where that tape may end up? He could be... bouncing it off some satellite or something. Some horny old men in South America or something could be watching it.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: He wouldn't do that.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You don't know that for sure.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Well, it's too late now, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Did he touch you?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No, but I did.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You touched him?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: In front of him, Ann, yes.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You are in trouble.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Listen to you!! You sound like Mom. What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I can't believe you did that!!

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I mean, I couldn't do that in front of John, even.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: You couldn't do it, period.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You know what I mean, you don't even know him!

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: I feel like I do.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: That doesn't mean you do. You can't possibly trust him, he's... perverted.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: He's harmless. He just sits around and looks at these tapes. What's the big deal?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: So he's got this catalogue of women touching themselves? That doesn't make you feel weird?

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: No. I don't think they all did what I did.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You are in serious trouble.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Ann, I don't understand why this freaks you out so much. You didn't do it, I did, and if it doesn't bother me, why should it bother you?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't want to discuss it.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Then why do you keep asking about it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Here it is.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It's a sun dress.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: It looks like a tablecloth.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It does not.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I was just trying to --

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: Hold on.

turns.speaker: CYNTHIA
turns.text: So what's my share of the dress?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Thirty-two dollars.
